[[Iris Apatow]] | website = {{URL|juddapatow.com}} }} '''Judd Apatow''' (born December 6, 1967) is an American producer, writer, director, actor and stand-up comedian. He is the founder of [[Apatow Productions]], through which he produced and developed the television series ''[[Freaks and Geeks]]'', ''[[Undeclared]]'', ''[[Girls (TV series)|Girls]], [[Love (TV series)|Love]]'', and ''[[Crashing (U.S. TV series)|Crashing]]'' and directed the films ''[[The 40-Year-Old Virgin]]'' (2005), ''[[Knocked Up]]'' (2007), ''[[Funny People]]'' (2009), ''[[This Is 40]]'' (2012), and ''[[Trainwreck (film)|Trainwreck]]'' (2015). Apatow's work has won numerous awards including a [[Primetime Emmy Award]], a Hollywood Comedy Award, and an [[American Film Institute#AFI Awards|AFI Award]] for ''[[Bridesmaids (2011 film)|Bridesmaids]]'' (2011).{{cite web|title=Behind the Scenes of THR's Judd Apatow Cover Shoot|date=December 13, 2012|url=http://www.hollywoodreporter.com/video/scenes-thrs-judd-apatow-cover-401034|work=[[The Hollywood Reporter]]|accessdate=July 1, 2013}}{{cite web|title=Deadline Hollywood|date=October 23, 2012|url=http://www.deadline.com/2012/10/358432|work=[[Deadline Hollywood]]|accessdate=November 11, 2012}} His films have also been nominated for [[Grammy Award]]s, [[PGA Awards]], [[Golden Globe Awards]], and [[Academy Awards]].{{citation needed|date=April 2018}} His producing credits include ''[[Anchorman: The Legend of Ron Burgundy]]'' (2004), ''[[Talladega Nights: The Ballad of Ricky Bobby]]'' (2006), ''[[Superbad (film)|Superbad]]'' (2007), ''[[Forgetting Sarah Marshall]]'' (2008), ''[[Pineapple Express (film)|Pineapple Express]]'' (2008), ''[[Get Him to the Greek]]'' (2010), ''[[Bridesmaids (2011 film)|Bridesmaids]]'' (2011), ''[[The Five-Year Engagement]]'' (2012), ''[[Anchorman 2: The Legend Continues]]'' (2013), ''[[Begin Again (film)|Begin Again]]'' (2014), ''[[Popstar: Never Stop Never Stopping]]'' (2016), and ''[[The Big Sick]]'' (2017). ==Early life and education== Judd Apatow was born in [[Flushing, Queens]], and raised in [[Syosset, New York|Syosset]], New York. Robert went to live with his maternal grandparents, and Mia went to live with her mother. As a child, Apatow lived mainly with his father, and visited his mother on weekends. Apatow's mother spent a summer working at a comedy club, which is where Judd was first exposed to live [[stand-up comedy]].{{cite web|title=Judd Apatow 30-year career timeline: from stand-up comedy to his "Knocked Up" spin-off|date=October 19, 2011|url=http://www.ifc.com/fix/2011/10/judd-apatow-career-timeline|publisher=IFC.com|accessdate=November 18, 2012}} Apatow was obsessed with comedy as a news|first=Rodrick|last=Stephen|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2007/05/27/magazine/27apatow-t.html|title=Judd Apatow's Family Values|work=[[The New York Times]]|date=May 27, 2007|accessdate=June 4, 2007}} Apatow got his comic start washing dishes at the Long Island East Side Comedy Club, and while attending [[Syosset High School]], he played jazz and hosted a program called ''Comedy Club'' on the school's 125-watt radio station [[WKWZ]] which he created as a way to meet and learn from the comedians he looked up to.{{cite web|title=Apatow: Funny People Father Figure|date=October 27, Know|first=Ryan|last=McKee|date=|website=askmen.com|accessdate=April 10, 2018}} ==Career== ===1985–2003: Stand-up, early film and television work=== Apatow began performing stand-up comedy at age seventeen, during his senior year of high school. In the September 1985 issue of ''Laugh Factory Magazine'', he is listed as an Associate Editor. After graduating from high school in 1985, he moved to Los Angeles and enrolled in the screenwriting program at [[University of Southern California]].{{cite web|url=http://cinema.usc.edu/alumni/notable.cfm|title=Sampling of Notable USC Alumni Working in Cinema/Television/Interactive|publisher=USC School of Cinematic Arts|accessdate=December 21, 2011}} While at USC, he organized and hosted a number of on-campus "Comedy Night" events, featuring headliners such as ''Saturday Night Live'' performer [[Kevin Nealon]]. Apatow introduced the acts at these events with short standup routines of his own. He also began volunteering at (and later producing) benefit concerts for HBO's [[Comic Relief (charity)|Comic Relief]] and performing and seeing standup at [[the Improv]] in Hollywood. He dropped out of college during his second year and later moved into an apartment with comedian [[Adam Sandler]], whom he met at the Improv. He competed in the Johnnie Walker Comedy Search in 1989 directed by ''Saturday Night Live'' short film producer [[Neal Marshad]].{{cite news|last=Abramowitz|first=Rachel|url=http://www.latimes.com/entertainment/news/la-ca-apatow13may13,1,1056915.story|title=The king of Geeks|work=[[Los Angeles Times]]|date=May 13, 2007|accessdate=June 4, 2007}} Shortly thereafter, Apatow was introduced by manager Jimmy Miller to [[Garry Shandling]] which resulted in Apatow being hired as a writer for the [[Grammy Awards]] that year, which Shandling hosted.{{cite news|last=Newman|first=Melinda|title=Man most likely to inspire|work=[[Daily Variety]]|date=October 29, 2012|accessdate=November 23, 2012}} In 1992, Apatow appeared on [[Home Box Office|HBO's]] ''15th Annual Young Comedians Special''{{cite news|last=Michaels|first=Chad|title=Judd Apatow Interview|publisher=Wild About Movies|date=May 23, 2007|url=http://www.wildaboutmovies.com/interviews/Judd-Apatow-Interview.php|accessdate=June 4, 2007}} and shortly afterwards went on to co-create and executive produce ''[[The Ben Stiller Show]]'' for [[Fox Broadcasting Company|Fox]]. Apatow had met Stiller outside of an [[Elvis Costello]] concert in 1990, and they became friends. Despite critical acclaim and an [[Emmy Award]] for Apatow and the rest of the writing staff, Fox canceled the show in 1993.{{cite news|last=Marcus |first=Bennett|url=http://www.vanityfair.com/online/daily/2012/11/judd-apatow-ben-stiller-show-comedy |title= Judd Apatow and Ben Stiller on The Ben Stiller Show and Comedy—and How Cult Followings Mean the Most|work=[[Vanity Fair (magazine)|Vanity Fair]]|date=November 12, 2012|accessdate=November 23, 2012}} Apatow went on to join HBO's ''[[The Larry Sanders Show]]'' in 1993 as a writer and consulting producer, and he later served as a co-executive producer and director of an episode during the show's final season in 1998. He credits Shandling as his mentor for influencing him to write comedy that is more character-driven. Apatow earned six [[Emmy]] nominations for his work on Larry Sanders. During this same time, he worked as a consulting producer and staff writer for the animated show ''[[The Critic]]'', starring [[Jon Lovitz]].{{cite news|last=Locker|first=Melissa|url=http://www.ifc.com/fix/2010/12/12-days-of-judd-apatow-day-5-t|title=12 Days of Judd Apatow: Day 5 "The Critic"|work=IFC|date=December 21, 2010|accessdate=November 23, 2012}} In 1995, Apatow co-wrote (with Steve Brill) the feature film ''[[Heavyweights]]''. Around the same time, Apatow was hired to produce and do an uncredited re-write of the script for the movie ''[[The Cable Guy]]'', which was released in 1996 to mixed reviews.{{cite news|last=Thompson|first=Anne|url=http://www.variety.com/article/VR1117964732.html?categoryid=2508&cs=1|title=Hot Apatow new king of comedy|work=[[Variety (magazine)|Variety]]|date=May 11, 2007|accessdate=June 4, 2007}} It was during the pre-production of the film that Apatow met his future wife, actress [[Leslie Mann]]. Apatow did uncredited re-writes on two other [[Jim Carrey]] films: ''[[Liar, Liar]]'' and ''[[Bruce Almighty]]''.{{cite news|last=Haberman|first=Lia|url=http://www.eonline.com/news/45301/diaz-and-carrey-reunited|title=Diaz and Carrey Reunited?|publisher=E!|date=June 11, 2003|accessdate=November 23, 2012}} His next script was titled ''Making Amends'', which had [[Owen Wilson]] attached to star as a man in [[Alcoholics Anonymous]] who decides to apologize to everyone he has ever hurt. However, the film was never made. Apatow did uncredited rewrites of the [[Adam Sandler]] films ''[[Happy Gilmore]]'' and ''[[The Wedding Singer]]''. He was also featured in four tracks on Sandler's 1996 comedy album "[[What the Hell Happened to Me?]]"{{cite web|author1=Eduardo Rivadavia (review)|title=What the Hell Happened to Me? - Adam Sandler|url=http://www.allmusic.com/album/what-the-hell-happened-to-me-mw0000179861|website=[[AllMusic]]|accessdate=July 29, 2016}} In 1999, Apatow created ''Sick in the Head'', a multi-camera sitcom pilot starring [[David Krumholtz]] as a psychiatrist on his first day on the job, [[Amy Poehler]] as a suicidal patient, and [[Kevin Corrigan]] as Krumholtz's slacker roommate.{{cite news|last=Evans|first=Bradford|url=http://splitsider.com/2011/05/the-lost-projects-of-judd-apatow|title=The Lost Projects of Judd Apatow|work=Splitsider|date=May 12, 2011|accessdate=November 23, 2012}} The show was not picked up by Fox, which freed up Apatow to serve as an executive producer of the award-winning series ''[[Freaks and Geeks]]'', which debuted in 1999. He also wrote and directed several episodes of the series. After its cancellation, Apatow was the executive producer and creator of the series ''[[Undeclared]]'', which reused [[Seth Rogen]] in the main cast and other ''Freaks and Geeks'' cast members in recurring roles. Although both shows were quickly canceled, ''[[USA Today]]'' media critic Susan Wloszczyna called the shows "two of the most acclaimed TV series to ever last only one season."{{cite news|last=Wloszczyna|first=Susan|url=https://www.usatoday.com/life/movies/news/2007-05-06-judd-apatow_N.htm|title=For Apatow, opportunity knocks|work=[[USA Today]]|accessdate=June 4, 2007|date=May 6, 2007}} In 2001, Apatow created ''Julie'', a pilot of his that featured [[Jason Segel]], [[Kevin Hart (actor)|Kevin Hart]], [[Seth Rogen]], [[Phil Hendrie]], and [[Judge Reinhold]] (playing himself). The pilot was not picked up by Fox.{{citation needed|date=April 2018}} In 2002, he co-wrote (with [[Brent Forrester]]) a Fox pilot titled ''Life on Parole'', starring [[David Herman]] as a dissatisfied [[parole officer]] whose roommate happens to be one of his parolees; it was not picked up. Apatow has screened and introduced them at "The Other Network", a festival of un-aired TV pilots produced by [[Un-Cabaret]]. He reunited with [[Jason Segel]] and [[Amy Poehler]] for the 2001 Fox sitcom pilot, ''North Hollywood''.{{citation needed|date=April 2018}} ===2004–2008: ''The 40-Year-Old Virgin'', ''Knocked Up'', and producing=== In 2004, Apatow [[film producer|produced]] the feature film comedy ''[[Anchorman: The Legend of Ron Burgundy]]'', starring [[Will Ferrell]] and directed by [[Adam McKay]]. The film was a box office success. Apatow co-produced the 2013 sequel, ''[[Anchorman 2: The Legend Continues]]''.{{cite news|last=Day|first=Patrick|url=http://latimesblogs.latimes.com/showtracker/2012/03/anchorman-2-will-ferrell-ron-burgundy-conan.html|title='Anchorman 2': Will Ferrell drops sequel news on 'Conan'|work=[[Los Angeles Times]]|accessdate=November 25, 2012|date=March 29, 2012}} He made his feature directorial debut in 2005 with the comedy ''[[The 40-Year-Old Virgin]]'', which he also co-wrote with the film's star, [[Steve Carell]], for [[Universal Pictures]]. The film opened at number one at the box office and grossed more than $175 million globally. The comedy garnered numerous awards and nominations, including being named one of [[American Film Institute|AFI]]'s Top Movies of the Year, as well as taking home Best Comedy Movie at the 11th annual Critics' Choice Awards.{{cite web|title=AFI Announces Their Selection of 2005's Best Movies|publisher=About.com|date=August 18, 2006|url=http://movies.about.com/od/awards/a/afi12005121105.htm|accessdate=November 25, 2012}} ''The 40-Year-Old Virgin'' also earned Apatow a nomination for Best Original Screenplay from the [[Writers Guild of America]] and received four [[MTV Movie Award]] nominations, including a win for Carell for Best Comedic Performance.{{cite news|last=Buckalew|first=Brett|title=No Longer a Feature Film ''Virgin''|publisher=Filmstew.com|date=August 18, 2006|url=http://www.filmstew.com/showArticle.aspx?ContentID=14646|accessdate=June 4, 2007}} His second film, the romantic comedy ''[[Knocked Up]]'', was released in June 2007 to wide critical acclaim. Apatow wrote the initial draft of the film on the set of ''[[Talladega Nights: The Ballad of Ricky Bobby|Talladega Nights]]''. The story concerns a slacker and a media personality (Rogen and Heigl, respectively) whose [[one-night stand]] results in an unintended pregnancy. In addition to being a critical success, the film was also a commercial hit, continuing Apatow's newfound mainstream success. [[File:Judd Apatow.jpg|thumbnail|Apatow in 2007]] In August 2007, Apatow produced the film ''[[Superbad (film)|Superbad]]'', which was written by [[Seth Rogen]] and his writing partner [[Evan Goldberg]]. A concept Rogen and Goldberg had created as teens, Apatow convinced Rogen to write the film as a vehicle for himself in 2000. Rogen and Goldberg finished writing the film, but were unable to find a studio interested in producing it. Apatow then enlisted Rogen and Goldberg to write ''[[Pineapple Express (film)|Pineapple Express]]'', a [[Drug culture|stoner]] action movie that he felt would be more commercial. After the success of ''Anchorman'' and ''The 40-Year-Old Virgin'', Apatow was still unable to sell both ''Superbad'' and ''Pineapple Express''; it was only after he produced the commercial hit ''[[Talladega Nights]]'' that [[Sony Pictures Entertainment]] decided to produce both. At this point, Rogen was unable to play the lead for ''Superbad'', as he had grown too old to play the part of Seth. Subsequently, he was cast in a supporting role as a police officer and friend [[Jonah Hill]] took his role as the high school student. Apatow credits Rogen for influencing him to make his work more "outrageously dirty." In August 2007, ''Superbad'' opened at No. 1 in the box office to critical acclaim, taking in $33 million in its opening weekend.{{cite news |last=Coyle |first=Jake |title=How Did 'Superbad' Top the Box Office? |work=NewsOK |agency=[[Associated Press]]|date=August 21, 2007 |url=http://newsok.com/article/3107893}} Industry insiders claimed Apatow was now a brand unto himself, creating movies geared toward older audiences, who would watch his movies even when the films delved into the teen genre.{{cite news|last=Dergarabedian|first=Paul|title=Paul D. Explains the Judd Apatow Phenomenon|work=[[New York (magazine)|New York]]|publisher=New York Media|date=August 20, 2007|url=http://nymag.com/daily/entertainment/2007/08/paul_dergarabedian_watch_paul_d.html|accessdate=August 26, 2007}} Apatow served as producer and co-writer along with director [[Jake Kasdan]] for the biopic spoof ''[[Walk Hard: The Dewey Cox Story|Walk Hard]]'' starring [[John C. Reilly]], [[Kristen Wiig]] and [[Jenna Fischer]], which was released in December 2007.{{cite web|last1=Dargis|first1=Manohla|title=Behind the Music, This Time for Laughs|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2007/12/21/movies/21walk.html|website=[[The New York Times]]|accessdate=July 29, 2016|date=December 21, 2007}} While the film received positive reviews,{{cite web|title=Walk Hard: The Dewey Cox Story (2007)|url=https://www.rottentomatoes.com/m/walk_hard/|publisher=[[Rotten Tomatoes]]|accessdate=July 29, 2016}} it did poorly commercially.{{cite web|title=Walk Hard: The Dewey Cox Story|url=http://www.boxofficemojo.com/movies/?id=walkhard.htm|publisher=[[Box Office Mojo]]|accessdate=July 29, 2016}} In 2008, he served as producer for ''[[Drillbit Taylor]]'' starring Owen Wilson and [[Leslie Mann]] and written by Seth Rogen, which opened in March and earned negative reviews. Apatow retracted his support for the movie, feeling it was not what he had initially envisioned.{{cite web|last1=Brevet|first1=Brad|title=Judd Apatow Disowns ‘Drillbit Taylor’|url=http://www.comingsoon.net/movies/news/525670-judd_apatow_disowns_drillbit_taylor|website=[[ComingSoon.net]]|accessdate=July 29, 2016|date=March 20, 2008}} For the rest of 2008, Apatow produced the comedy films ''[[Forgetting Sarah Marshall]]'' starring [[Jason Segel]] and [[Kristen Bell]]; ''[[Step Brothers (film)|Step Brothers]]'', which reunites ''Talladega Nights'' co-stars [[Will Ferrell]] and [[John C. Reilly]]; and ''[[Pineapple Express (film)|Pineapple Express]]'' starring Seth Rogen and [[James Franco]], both of whom originally starred on ''Freaks and Geeks''. In addition, he served as co-writer for the [[Adam Sandler]] comedy film ''[[You Don't Mess with the Zohan]]'', which Sandler and [[Robert Smigel]] also co-wrote.{{cite web|last1=Leitch|first1=Will|last2=Grierson|first2=Tim|title=Every Judd Apatow Movie, Ranked From Worst to Best|url=http://www.vulture.com/2015/07/every-apatow-movie-ranked-from-worst-to-best.html|website=Vulture|publisher=[[New York (magazine)|New York]]|accessdate=July 29, 2016|date=June 7, 2016}} He tries to keep a low budget on his projects and usually makes his movies about the work itself rather than using big stars. After his success in film, he hired the entire writing staff from ''Undeclared'' to write movies for [[Apatow Productions]]. He never fires writers and he keeps them on projects through all stages of productions, known colloquially as "the comedy wheel." Apatow is not committed to any specific studio, but his projects are typically set up at [[Universal Pictures|Universal]] and [[Sony Pictures Entertainment|Sony]], and in 2009 ''[[Variety (magazine)|Variety]]'' reported that Universal had signed him to a 3 picture directing deal.{{cite news|last=Fleming|first=Michael|title=Universal embraces Judd Apatow|work=Variety|date=July 30, 2009|url=http://www.variety.com/article/VR1118006715?refCatId=13|accessdate=December 1, 2012}} Apatow once vowed to include a penis in every one of his movies.{{cite news|last=Branney|first=John|title=Is Hollywood A No-Members Club|work=[[The Guardian]]|date=August 26, 2008|url=https://www.theguardian.com/film/filmblog/2008/aug/26/hasthefigleaffallen|accessdate=April 23, 2009|quote=In an attempt to rid America of its phallophobia, Judd Apatow once vowed to include a penis in every one of his movies. |location=London}} He explained his position as, "I like movies that are, you know, uplifting and hopeful...and I like filth!"{{cite news|last=Walker|first=Tim|title=King of bromance: Judd Apatow|work=The Independent|date=August 19, 2009|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/arts-entertainment/films/features/king-of-bromance-judd-apatow-1773842.html|accessdate=November 14, 2010|quote=Says Apatow: "I like movies that are, you know, up-lifting and hopeful ... and I like filth."|location=London, UK}} ===2009–2015: ''Funny People'', ''This is 40'', and ''Trainwreck''=== [[Image:Funny People 6807.jpg|thumb|left|Apatow (right) with [[Leslie Mann]] and [[Adam Sandler]] in Berlin (2009)]] In 2009, Apatow served as producer for the biblical comedy film ''[[Year One (film)|Year one]]''; the film was not well received.{{cite web|title=Year One (2009)|url=https://www.rottentomatoes.com/m/year_one/|publisher=[[Rotten Tomatoes]]|accessdate=July 29, 2016}} He also released his third directorial feature on July 31 that same year, titled ''[[Funny People]]''. Apatow wrote the film, which starred [[Adam Sandler]] and [[Seth Rogen]] as a pair of standup comedians, one of whom has a terminal illness. Other co-stars included his wife [[Leslie Mann]] and [[Eric Bana]], who was a comedic actor in Australia before appearing in American films. In 2015, he was honored by the Rape Treatment Foundation, who later released a statement on Apatow’s contributions, describing him as “a powerful voice for the truths about rape and an advocate for respectful treatment of victims.”http://therapefoundation.org/2016/04/the-rape-foundation-2015-annual-brunch/ In 2017, Apatow was awarded the ACLU Bill of Rights Award, for being “an outspoken and tireless advocate on behalf of women in the arts.https://deadline.com/2017/11/aclu-southern-california-awards-judd-apatow-viola-davis-jane-fonda-gina-rodriguez-reginald-hudlin-dolores-huerta-1202201350/ ===Allegations of hypocrisy=== Apatow has positioned himself at the forefront of the "#MeToo" and "#TimesUp" online movements, encouraging alleged victims to come forward while also heavily criticising people accused without [[due process]]. Apatow had strong words for people like [[Bill Cosby]] and those who gave Cosby a platform to continue to perform and speak.{{cite web|title=Business Insider|url=http://www.businessinsider.com/judd-apatow-blasts-bill-cosby-2015-7}}{{cite web|title=Judd Apatow blasts Centre in the Square for hosting Bill Cosby|url=http://www.cbc.ca/news/canada/kitchener-waterloo/judd-apatow-blasts-centre-in-the-square-for-hosting-bill-cosby-1.2884922|website=cbc.com|publisher=CBC}} He has been criticized, however, for staying quiet about people accused within his own circles, such as [[James Franco]] and his mentor [[Garry Shandling]].{{cite web|title=Judd Apatow has been vocal against Bill Cosby. So why did he let an accused sexual offender on his new Netflix show?|url=https://www.vox.com/2016/2/24/11096636/andy-dick-netflix-love|website=vox.com|publisher=Vox}}{{cite web|title=Judd Apatow Strikes Down Diane Keaton’s Woody Allen Defense, but What About James Franco?|url=https://www.themarysue.com/judd-apatow-diane-keaton/|website=themarysue.com|publisher=The Mary Sue}}{{cite web|title=JHollywood Harassment: I Was Fired from a Hit Show and Intimidated By Lawyers|url=https://www.hollywoodreporter.com/news/hollywood-harassment-i-was-fired-a-hit-show-intimidated-by-lawyers-guest-column-1053465|work=The Hollywood Reporter}}{{cite web|title=Sitcom Writer Janis Hirsch Recalls Being Harassed and Humiliated While Working on It’s Garry Shandling's Show|url=http://www.vulture.com/2017/10/sitcom-writer-recalls-harassment-on-garry-shandlings-show.html|website=vulture.com|publisher=Vulture}} ==Awards== In 1993, he was one of the writers awarded an [[Emmy Award]] for "[[Primetime Emmy Award for Outstanding Writing for a Variety, Music or Comedy Program|Outstanding Writing for a Variety, Music or Comedy Program]]" for his work on ''[[The Ben Stiller Show]]'' at the [[45th Primetime Emmy Awards]].
